articleinfo.title: Ulteo Open Virtual Desktop - Protocol Description

article.para: The purpose of this documentation is to describe the protocols used by Ulteo Open Virtual Desktop.

section.title: Hyper Text Transfert Protocol (HTTP)
section.para: The base communication protocol used is HTTP because of the Web based solution. But we also use HTTP for the communication between servers: Session Manager to Application Server and vice versa. This protocol runs over TCP on the port 80. We are not using HTTPS (443) at the moment.
The Administration Console is a Web site too.

section.title: Remote Frame Buffer (RFB)
section.para: RFB is the protocol used to display the remote desktop and applications inside the Web broswer. This protocol is used by VNC. VNC runs over TCP too. A VNC server runs one instance by desktop so one port for each display. The classic port used by VNC is 5900.
For Ulteo Open Virtual Desktop, we are using port between 5900 and 6000.

section.title: Secure Shell (SSH)
section.para: SSH is a protocol used to access to a machine over a network. SSH uses encryption to make sure that no one on the network can decrypt what the user does.
We are using SSH to tunnelize the RFB stream because RFB is not encprypted.

section.title: Servers Communication
section.para: The servers communicate by HTTP using webservices.
The Session Manager identifies an Application servers using its Fully Qualified Domain Name (FQDN).
The Applications servers only answer to the Session Manager for which the address is stored in a configuration file. (SESSION_MANAGER_URL).

section.title: Security
section.para: At the moment, the server are authenticated using the DNS resolution system.

When an Application server sends a status, it sends an extra argument named fqdn. The Session Manager makes 2 authentications test and 1 authorization.
fqdn resoltuion: resolves the fqdn to get an ip address and tests if it matches with the remove server ip ($SERVER['REMOTE_ADDR'] in php). Authentication directly depends on this match
reverse resoltuion: resolves the server ip address and tests if it matches the fqdn argument. Authentication directly depends on this match. This test can be disabled in the administration console using the Disable fqdn check
authorisation: tests the match of the fqdn with one of the Authorized fqdn defined in the admin console.

section.title: HTTP return codes
section.para: Webservices are using the HTTP return code to know if the request succeeded.

listitem.para: 400 Bad Request : request argument no valid
401 Unauthorized : From SM to ApS, ApS detects that remote address is not its SM. From ApS to SM, ApS is not registered yet or has invalid authentication.
500 Internal Server Error : Either a bug was detected on the system or the system is broken.

section.title: Session Manager webservices
section.para: The webservices used for the servers communication are in /webservices.

simplesect.title: server_status.php
simplesect.para: An application server sends his status at startup, when it stops or when an important error occured. That's the way the system can know when an offline server is online again or when a server needs to be registred.

simplesect.title: server_monitoring.php
simplesect.para: Applications servers send periodically their system information in order to know the status of each server. This is used for the session load balancing for instance.
The monitoring contains the CPU and RAM load. But also the running applications for each sessions.

simplesect.title: session_status.php
simplesect.para: Applications servers send, for each session, the status each time it changes.

simplesect.title: session_token.php
simplesect.para: When an user is launches a session, he is redirected with a token to an application server. To verify the user identity and get the session informations, the application server uses this token on its Session Manager and if valid, get informations as XML content.

simplesect.title: icons.php
simplesect.para: Get the icon for an application in order to display it in the user desktop. The application server uses a cache system so an application icon is only asked one time by a server.

simplesect.title: app_desktopfile.php

listitem.para: returns: application informations as XML content

simplesect.para: Get the application informations from the desktopfile argument in order to create the application shortcut on the user's desktop.

section.title: Application Server webservices
section.para: The webservices used for the servers communication are in /webservices.

simplesect.title: server_status.php
simplesect.para: Session Manager asks for the server status periodically to update the status if needed and auto detect down or broken servers.

simplesect.title: session_status.php
simplesect.para: Session Manager asks for each session status periodically to auto detect servers/sessions craches.

simplesect.title: server_monotoring.php
simplesect.para: Session Manager asks for the server monitoring when it detects too old cache informations.

simplesect.title: appplications.php

listitem.para: returns: applications list as XML content

simplesect.para: Get the installed applications on the system.

simplesect.title: kill_session.php
simplesect.para: Force a specific session to exit without notifying the user.

simplesect.title: server_version.php
simplesect.para: Get the server version. On Windows, get the Windows long version. On Linux, get the content of /etc/issue.

simplesect.title: server_type.php
simplesect.para: Get the server type.

simplesect.title: icon.php
simplesect.para: Extracts the icon associated to an application.

section.title: Client/Servers communication
section.para: Once the client is redirected to the ApS, he only requests this server, not the SM (except for session sharing as described bellow).
The session displayed is encapsulated in a SSH tunnel but webservices are also used to communicate. For instance, for printing.

simplesect.title: startsession.php

listitem.para: height: the desired height of the session
width: the desired width of the session

simplesect.para: This webservice is called when whatsup returned 0 as session status. startsession sets the session status to 1.

simplesect.title: whatsup.php

listitem.para: returns: session informations as XML content

simplesect.para: The webservice has serveral uses. First of all, it's used to know that the user is still connected (a kind of ping timeout process). Secondly, it allows the client to know session status changes. And finally, it is used to know when a new pdf file is ready for download.
The client has to call this webservice every 10 seconds maximum or there is a risk that the session timeout is triggered.

simplesect.title: client_exit.php
simplesect.para: This webservice can be called when the users close the session window to force the session to exit instead of waiting the timeout trigger.
This is usefull on session sharing for instance to be sure that when the client exits, all users sharing the session cannot still access it.

simplesect.title: print.php

listitem.para: timestamp: a time refered to the pdf file time to download

simplesect.para: This webserice is the way to transport the print jobs from the session to the client.

On the ApS, there is a PDF printer that spools file in the session directory. When there is a new file, whatsup detects it, extracts the timestamp and alerts the client. The client just has to request a print with the timestamp to get the print job and use a mean to print localy (print applet).

section.title: Session status
section.para: The status sent by webservices and used by both systems (Session Manager and Application server) are integer.

section.title: Jobs status
section.para: When installing/removing applications using the apt-get webservice, the Administration console requests the ApS to know the status of the job.

listitem.para: -2: job made an error, system can switch in broken mode
